Cooperative Federated Learning over Ground-to-Satellite Integrated Networks: Joint Local Computation and Data Offloading

Dong-Jun Han,  Seyyedali Hosseinalipour,  David J. Love,  Mung Chiang,  Christopher G. Brinton This work was supported in part by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) under Grant D22AP00168, in part by the National Science Foundation (NSF) under Grant CNS-2212565, and in part by the Office of Naval Research (ONR) under Grant N000142112472. D.-J. Han, D. J. Love, M. Chiang and C. G. Brinton are with the Elmore Family School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, USA (e-mail: han762@purdue.edu; djlove@purdue.edu; chiang@purdue.edu; cgb@purdue.edu). S. Hosseinalipour is with the Department of Electrical Engineering, University at Buffalo–SUNY, NY, USA (email: alipour@buffalo.edu).
Abstract

While network coverage maps continue to expand, many devices located in remote areas remain unconnected to terrestrial communication infrastructures, preventing them from getting access to the associated data-driven services. In this paper, we propose a ground-to-satellite cooperative federated learning (FL) methodology to facilitate machine learning service management over remote regions. Our methodology orchestrates satellite constellations to provide the following key functions during FL: (i) processing data offloaded from ground devices, (ii) aggregating models within device clusters, and (iii) relaying models/data to other satellites via inter-satellite links (ISLs). Due to the limited coverage time of each satellite over a particular remote area, we facilitate satellite transmission of trained models and acquired data to neighboring satellites via ISL, so that the incoming satellite can continue conducting FL for the region. We theoretically analyze the convergence behavior of our algorithm, and develop a training latency minimizer which optimizes over satellite-specific network resources, including the amount of data to be offloaded from ground devices to satellites and satellites’ computation speeds. Through experiments on three datasets, we show that our methodology can significantly speed up the convergence of FL compared with terrestrial-only and other satellite baseline approaches.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, LEO satellites, ground-to-satellite integrated networks

I Introduction

In the era of big data, a plethora of valuable datasets are being collected by geo-distributed edge devices, such as smartphones, vehicles, and Internet-of-Things (IoT) sensors. Demand to leverage this data for intelligent services continues to grow. Motivated by this, federated learning (FL) [1, 2, 3] has been actively studied in recent years and has now become the de facto standard for training a machine learning (ML) model across distributed nodes. By taking advantage of terrestrial communication infrastructures, FL has achieved a great success in both single server architectures [1, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8] and hierarchical setups [9, 10, 11, 12] with multiple edge servers.

I-A Motivation and Challenge

Motivation: FL across remote areas. Despite the wide deployment of mobile communication systems in current terrestrial networks, there still exist many isolated regions on the Earth (e.g., rural regions, maritime areas) that lack a well-developed communication infrastructure. Since neither the servers nor the access points are available/reachable in these areas, it is currently difficult to conduct FL across devices located in such regions. Although fully decentralized FL schemes have been developed [13, 14, 15, 16], which remove the reliance on edge servers, these methods have limitations when connections among devices are unstable (e.g., isolated regions with distant edge devices).

To facilitate collaborative training across these disconnected devices, we take advantage of Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites in FL. The explosive growth in the number of LEO satellites enables the non-terrestrial network to cover most of the regions on the Earth, enabling satellites to work as a model aggregator during FL in remote areas. Especially when it is required to conduct FL across multiple remote clusters that are geographically separated (as in Fig. 1), existing FL techniques, which mostly utilize terrestrial networks, face significant challenges as the devices in different regions are not able to aggregate their models without the aid of non-terrestrial networks, e.g., satellites. Introducing satellites to FL also enables low-powered ground devices in isolated regions to benefit from the computation capabilities of satellites, due to the advancement of on-board processing technology for satellites [17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23].

Exemplary use cases. Consider a scenario of training an ML model for natural disaster predictions (e.g., wildfire, hurricane, landslides). In order to reliably make decisions for these disasters, it is important to utilize data collected at IoT sensors distributed across different isolated areas, such as forests, oceans, and mountains. Another key application could be autonomous vehicles, which necessitates collaboration among vehicles in different regions, including rural areas that lack a well-developed communication infrastructure. Other examples include hospitals, smartphones, or wearable devices located in different rural regions aiming to solve a classification task for diseases-prediction. These use cases motivate integrating terrestrial networks with the satellite network that has a wide coverage across different remote regions and sufficient computation powers for FL.

Satellite-based computing/learning. With the ever increasing development of space communication networks, LEO satellites are currently regarded as a promising solution to achieve ubiquitous connection in 6G-and-beyond wireless. The densely deployed LEO satellites enable clients located in isolated regions to receive both high-quality communication and fast computation services. Motivated by this, there has been an extensive work on satellite-assisted edge computing [17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23], where satellites process tasks offloaded from low-powered IoT devices. Although these works pave the way to integrate satellites in wireless networks, their focus is not on ML/FL. More recently, researchers have become interested in conducting FL using data samples directly collected at satellites [24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31] without consider.

Key questions. Despite the above mentioned works, utilization of satellites to assist FL across different remote terrestrial regions has been less explored. In this work, we aim to explore this topic, which is faced with several key challenges and research questions. First, what should be the roles of the satellites in assisting FL across remote areas? How much data should be offloaded from the ground devices to the satellites in each region for training? How should the satellite-side battery issue be handled during FL? How can we handle the limited coverage time of LEO satellites over each area? How can we guarantee convergence of a satellite-assisted FL algorithm? How should we optimize the network resources to minimize the training time? To the best of our knowledge, this work is among the first attempts to address these research questions.

I-B Main Contributions

In this paper, we propose a ground-to-satellite cooperative FL methodology that provides a novel direction for utilizing satellites in FL. In order to facilitate efficient FL across different remote areas or clusters, we use each satellite as (i) an edge computing unit for processing data offloaded from the ground users, (ii) a server for aggregating the models within each cluster, (iii) a relay for sharing the model/data with other satellites via inter-satellite links (ISLs).

Compared to the traditional FL in terrestrial networks, one of the key challenges that arises in this ground-to-satellite integrated network is that the satellites are continuously moving following their orbits, limiting the coverage time of satellites for each cluster. To handle this issue, we propose to let each satellite transmit its trained model and data offloaded from the clients to its neighboring satellite (that will cover the same region in a near future) via ISL, so that the incoming satellite can continue training the model for the devices located in that region. We conduct convergence analysis of our FL algorithm, and optimize various network resources including the amount of data offloading, satellite-side computation power, and user bandwidth, to minimize the overall latency of ML model training. Another unique challenge of our setup is to deal with the satellite-side battery constraints. We consider solar-powered satellites having solar panels where the batteries could be charged via the sun. Hence, more data can be offloaded to the satellites when clusters are facing the sun, and those satellites can process data with higher computation powers with less battery issues. These aspects are integrated in our formulated network optimization problem.

Our main contributions can be summarized as follows:

  • •

    We propose a satellite-assisted FL methodology that enables ground users in different remote areas to collaboratively train an ML model, based on hybrid client-side local computation, ground-to-satellite data offloading, satellite-side model training, satellite-assisted intra-cluster aggregation, and satellite-to-satellite model/data transmissions.

  • •

    Based on the objective function defined with satellite-side and client-side local losses in each cluster, we theoretically analyze the convergence behavior of our FL algorithm with respect to the amount of data processed at individual satellites and ground devices, and guarantee its convergence to a stationary point of general non-convex loss functions.

  • •

    We formulate a network optimization problem to minimize latency, and optimize satellite-specific key design elements including the amount of data to be offloaded from each ground user to each satellite and satellites’ computation powers, while considering the battery constraints of solar-powered satellites.

  • •

    In simulations, we adopt three benchmark datasets for FL and show that our methodology can significantly speed up the convergence of FL compared with baselines by strategically taking advantage of satellites’ resources. We also provide key insights into the effects of data offloading depending on whether the cluster is facing the sun or not.

To the best of our knowledge, this is one of the earliest works to provide an analysis on FL over ground-to-satellite integrated networks with theoretical guarantee and optimized design elements. Our solution provides new guidelines on how to utilize satellites in FL, with several unique characteristics including the impact of battery charging of solar-powered satellites, and satellite-to-satellite model/data transmissions.

I-C Related Works

FL over terrestrial networks. Most existing works on FL have been developed in a terrestrial network with a single cloud server [1, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 32] or with multiple edge servers [9, 10, 11, 12, 33]. In these works, the role of the server is to aggregate the models sent from the clients. Research has been also conducted in a fully decentralized setup [13, 14, 15, 16] where the models are aggregated at individual clients, without requiring any servers. However, when clients in different remote regions need to collaboratively train an ML model without relying on terrestrial communications, these FL techniques face great challenges.

FL over satellites/UAVs. Motivated by the recent proliferation of LEO satellites and the advancement of their computation capabilities, there has been a line of works focusing on FL over satellites [25, 24, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31], where data samples are directly collected at the satellites. The satellites can be viewed as clients, and perform local updates using their local datasets. The main focus of these works is to investigate where/how to aggregate the trained models after the satellite-side local updates. The authors of [24, 26, 27, 28, 31] specifically study model aggregation strategies by utilizing the ground station as a server, where [26, 31] specifically adopt ISL communications during the aggregation process. FL has been also studied in unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) networks, where the UAVs collect data and act as clients [34, 35, 36]. Compared to these works where either the LEO satellites or the UAVs are viewed as clients, we focus on a different scenario where clients are located in isolated regions on the ground. Our problem setup necessitates satellites to have additional functions to process data offloaded from the ground users, to aggregate the models within the cluster, and to relay model/data to another satellite via ISL communications to continue model training for the cluster.

Satellite-assisted computing/learning for ground users. Another line of works focus on satellite-based edge computing [17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23] to develop computation offloading strategies to the satellites. However, their focus is not on ML/FL. The key difference between these literatures and our setup is that, we require clients to collaboratively train a shared ML model across different regions, while the clients in prior works just need to solve their own computational tasks independently. The collaborative ML task in our setup requires satellites to aggregate and relay models to theoretically guarantee the convergence of FL, making the problem totally different.

Only a few prior works [37, 38, 39, 40] have focused on satellite-assisted distributed ML as in our setup, where the ground users aim at constructing an ML model assisted by the satellites. This problem setup is fundamentally different from the settings in [25, 24, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31] where each satellite directly collects its local data, presenting new research questions on what the roles of the satellites should be. The recent magazine paper [38] discusses possible scenarios of utilizing satellites as edge computing servers or relays during FL. In [37], the authors specifically focus on training the deep Q network (DQN) model for optimizing the action selection policy in the maze problem. In [39, 40], the satellite is also adopted as a server to aggregate the models trained at the ground devices in wireless settings. In [41], the authors consider data offloading in UAV-assisted FL. Compared to prior works, our contribution is to design a satellite-assisted FL strategy with several unique characteristics including client-to-satellite data offloading, hybrid satellite/client model training, battery charging of solar-powered LEO satellites, and model/data transmissions between incoming and departing satellites.

I-D Organization

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II illustrates the system model and overview of approach, while Section III presents our satellite-assisted FL algorithm. Theoretical convergence analysis and network optimization results are provided in Section IV and Section V, respectively. We present experimental results in Section VI, and draw conclusions in Section VII.

II System Model and Overview of Approach

Consider a set 𝒥𝒥\mathcal{J} of J𝐽J different clusters located in different remote areas that are geographically separated. We also consider a set 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} of K𝐾K users or clients distributed across these J𝐽J clusters, where each user belongs to a single cluster. Fig. 1 shows an example with J=3𝐽3J=3 clusters and K=9𝐾9K=9 clients. Let Gjsubscript𝐺𝑗G_{j} be the set of client indices located in cluster j∈𝒥𝑗𝒥j\in\mathcal{J}. The users in these clusters are not supported by terrestrial communication infrastructures. In order to facilitate FL across clients located in these remote regions, we consider LEO satellites moving around the Earth following their own orbits. Individual clusters can be supported by the satellites from different orbits, or possibly the same orbit depending on their locations. Each client k𝑘k has its own local dataset Dk=Dkc∪Dkssubscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑐superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑠D_{k}=D_{k}^{c}\cup D_{k}^{s} with Dkc∩Dks=∅superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑐superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑠D_{k}^{c}\cap D_{k}^{s}=\emptyset, where Dkcsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑐D_{k}^{c} is the set of privacy-sensitive samples of client k𝑘k that should be necessarily kept in each client, while Dkssuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑠D_{k}^{s} is the set of non-sensitive samples that can be possibly offloaded to the satellite. The sensitive and non-sensitive data samples can be distinguished at each client based on the (i) locations of collected data, (ii) class information of data, or (iii) some other predetermined information depending on the specific task.

Solar-powered satellites. In each time slot, the overall J𝐽J cluster sets {Gj}j=1Jsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐺𝑗𝑗1𝐽\{G_{j}\}_{j=1}^{J} in the system can be divided into two different categories depending on their locations. First are the clusters in which the satellites covering the region can charge their batteries via the sun. This becomes possible when cluster j𝑗j is facing the sun and the corresponding satellites’ solar panels have no orientation issues for charging. We define 𝒥sunsuperscript𝒥sun\mathcal{J}^{\text{sun}} as the set of the corresponding cluster indices: The batteries of LEO satellites covering the clusters in j∈𝒥sun𝑗superscript𝒥sunj\in\mathcal{J}^{\text{sun}} will have less battery issues at the satellites due to the solar power. On the other hand, the batteries of satellites covering the remaining clusters (i.e., j∈𝒥∖𝒥sun𝑗𝒥superscript𝒥sunj\in\mathcal{J}\setminus\mathcal{J}^{\text{sun}}) are not able to be charged, which will result in relatively strict energy constraints.

Goal and overview of approach. Under this system model, the goal of the ground users is to construct a shared global model 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} that well reflects all data samples in J𝐽J clusters in the system. Fig. 1 describes the high-level overview of our approach. As a preprocessing step, the resource-limited clients offload specific portions of their local datasets to the corresponding satellite as in Fig. 1(a). Then in Fig. 1(b), each client performs local updates using its remaining data samples, while each satellite performs local updates using data offloaded from the clients. Here, due to the limited coverage time of each satellite over each cluster, we let each satellite transmits the trained model and the collected dataset to the neighboring satellite that will cover the same cluster in the near future. As a result, the incoming satellite can continue training the model for the specific cluster. This procedure is repeated until all data samples at the satellite are processed. Then in Fig. 1(c), intra-cluster model aggregation is performed to construct cluster-specific models. Finally, in Fig. 1(d), a global model is constructed by aggregating the models of all clusters, which is sent back to all clients at the beginning of next global round.

III Proposed Algorithm

The step in Fig. 1(a) is a preprocessing step that occurs only once before training begins, while the other steps in Figs. 1(b), 1(c), 1(d) are repeated for R𝑅R global rounds, which we index r=0,1,…,R−1𝑟01…𝑅1r=0,1,\dots,R-1. In each round r𝑟r, the global model 𝐰rsuperscript𝐰𝑟\mathbf{w}^{r} is constructed by synchronously aggregating the satellite models at the ground station as in [26, 31]. We propose all LEO satellites to play the following key roles simultaneously during training: Each satellite work as an (i) edge computing unit for updating the model using data samples offloaded from the clients, as a (ii) server for intra-cluster model aggregation, and as a (iii) relay for sharing the updated model and data to other satellites via ISL communications. Based on these unique characteristics of our framework, in the following, we will describe our methodology with details.

III-A Preprocessing step: Data Offload to Satellites

Consider a specific cluster set Gjsubscript𝐺𝑗G_{j}. Before training begins, as a preprocessing step, each client k∈Gj𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗k\in G_{j} offloads a subset of non-sensitive dataset D^ks⊂Dkssuperscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑠\hat{D}_{k}^{s}\subset D_{k}^{s} to the corresponding satellite that is currently covering cluster j𝑗j, as shown in Fig. 1(a). Here, we introduce our key design parameter

αk=|D^ks||Dk|,subscript𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠subscript𝐷𝑘\alpha_{k}=\frac{|\hat{D}_{k}^{s}|}{|D_{k}|}, (1)

which is the portion of data samples offloaded from client k𝑘k to the satellite. Here, for an arbitrary dataset D𝐷D, we use |D|𝐷|D| to denote the number of data samples in D𝐷D. We have 0≤αk≤αkmax0subscript𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘max0\leq\alpha_{k}\leq\alpha_{k}^{\text{max}}, where αkmax=|Dks|/|Dk|superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘maxsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑠subscript𝐷𝑘\alpha_{k}^{\text{max}}=|D_{k}^{s}|/|D_{k}| is the portion of non-sensitive samples in client k𝑘k which may depend on the specific ML application (e.g., IoT sensors for disaster predictions may have large αkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘max\alpha_{k}^{\text{max}} while personal vehicles may have smaller αkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘max\alpha_{k}^{\text{max}}).

III-B Step 1: Client-Side Local Training

In the beginning of each round r𝑟r, all clients and satellites have model 𝐰rsuperscript𝐰𝑟\mathbf{w}^{r}. As in Fig. 1(b), each client k𝑘k locally trains the model using D^kc=Dk∖D^kssuperscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑐subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠\hat{D}_{k}^{c}=D_{k}\setminus\hat{D}_{k}^{s}, which is the remaining dataset after the data offloading step in Section III-A. Here, we introduce another variable γkrsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑟\gamma_{k}^{r}, which is the portion of data samples that client k𝑘k processes during the model update at a specific round r𝑟r. By defining λC,krsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝐶𝑘𝑟\lambda_{C,k}^{r} as the number of samples being processed at client k𝑘k at a specific round r𝑟r, we can write

γkr=λC,kr|Dk|.superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜆𝐶𝑘𝑟subscript𝐷𝑘\gamma_{k}^{r}=\frac{\lambda_{C,k}^{r}}{|D_{k}|}. (6)

Here, since 0<λC,kr≤|D^kc|=(1−αk)​|Dk|0superscriptsubscript𝜆𝐶𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑐1subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘0<\lambda_{C,k}^{r}\leq|\hat{D}_{k}^{c}|=(1-\alpha_{k})|D_{k}| holds, we have 0<γkr≤1−αk0superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑟1subscript𝛼𝑘0<\gamma_{k}^{r}\leq 1-\alpha_{k}. One possible solution is to let each client k𝑘k process all the remaining data samples by setting γkr=1−αksuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑟1subscript𝛼𝑘\gamma_{k}^{r}=1-\alpha_{k}. In specific time-sensitive applications, one can also set a smaller γkrsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑟\gamma_{k}^{r} to further reduce the training time at low-powered IoT devices/sensors in remote regions. Taking a small γkrsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑟\gamma_{k}^{r} will reduce the training time at each device, with the cost of degraded learning performance, as we will see later in the convergence analysis in Section IV. For each client k𝑘k, the local update process becomes

𝐰C,kr+1=𝐰r−ηr​∇~​ℓC,k​(𝐰r),subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑟1𝐶𝑘superscript𝐰𝑟subscript𝜂𝑟~∇subscriptℓ𝐶𝑘superscript𝐰𝑟\mathbf{w}^{r+1}_{C,k}=\mathbf{w}^{r}-\eta_{r}\tilde{\nabla}\ell_{C,k}(\mathbf{w}^{r}), (7)

The computation time τC,klocalsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑘local\tau_{C,k}^{\text{local}} (in seconds) to finish the local update at client k𝑘k is written as

τC,klocal=mC,k​γkr​|Dk|fC,k,superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑘localsubscript𝑚𝐶𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑟subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑓𝐶𝑘\tau_{C,k}^{\text{local}}=\frac{m_{C,k}\gamma_{k}^{r}|D_{k}|}{f_{C,k}}, (8)

Here, mC,ksubscript𝑚𝐶𝑘m_{C,k} is a fixed value that can be obtained offline at each client k𝑘k as assumed in [42, 43]. III-C Step 2: Repeated Satellite-Side Computation and ISL Communication (working in parallel with Step 1)

While the clients are performing local updates in Step 1, the satellite covering cluster j𝑗j also performs model update based on the dataset ∪k∈GjD^kssubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠\cup_{k\in G_{j}}\hat{D}_{k}^{s} offloaded from the clients in the cluster set Gjsubscript𝐺𝑗G_{j}. We let the satellite that is covering cluster j𝑗j perform local updates until it processes all the data samples in ∪k∈GjD^kssubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠\cup_{k\in G_{j}}\hat{D}_{k}^{s}. However, since each satellite is continuously moving following its own orbit, the coverage time of the satellite over each cluster limited. As a result, the satellite may not finish the computation before leaving cluster j𝑗j. We let this coverage time of the satellite for each cluster to be T𝑇T111In practice, the coverage time provided by each successive satellite varies over time according to the satellite constellation model. In such cases, T𝑇T can be obtained by taking the average of coverage times of future satellites and used for optimization. We show later that this approach works well in practical constellation models. Exploring a precise optimization algorithm considering varying coverage times is an interesting direction for future research.. Whenever a specific satellite leaves cluster j𝑗j after T𝑇T seconds, a new satellite in the same or adjacent orbit will start covering cluster j𝑗j. Motivated by this characteristic of the satellite network, we propose to let the satellite transmit the collected dataset ∪k∈GjD^kssubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠\cup_{k\in G_{j}}\hat{D}_{k}^{s} and the trained model to the new satellite before leaving cluster j𝑗j, so that the incoming satellite can continue the training process for cluster j𝑗j. When the last satellite for cluster j𝑗j finishes computation for the global round, it transmits the data/model to the new satellite for the next global round. Fig. 1(b) describes this process in a high-level. Specifically, our idea is to repeat the below two steps multiple times until all the samples in ∪k∈GjD^kssubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠\cup_{k\in G_{j}}\hat{D}_{k}^{s} are processed.

Step 2-1: Transmissions of data and model via ISL. Before a satellite joins cluster j𝑗j, it receives the model and data from the previous satellite that is leaving cluster j𝑗j. The communication time for this process can be written as

τS,jtrans=S​(𝐰)+q​∑k∈Gjαk​|Dk|QjISL,superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗trans𝑆𝐰𝑞subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑗ISL\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}}=\frac{S(\mathbf{w})+q\sum_{k\in G_{j}}\alpha_{k}|D_{k}|}{Q_{j}^{\text{ISL}}}, (10)

where S​(𝐰)𝑆𝐰S(\mathbf{w}) denotes the size of the model (in bits), q𝑞q is the size of each data sample (in bits), QjISLsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝑗ISLQ_{j}^{\text{ISL}} is the transmission rate for ISL between two adjacent satellites in cluster j𝑗j. Here, S​(𝐰)𝑆𝐰S(\mathbf{w}) can be calculated based on the number of model parameters in 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} and the type of quantization applied to individual parameters (e.g., S​(𝐰)=32×|𝐰|𝑆𝐰32𝐰S(\mathbf{w})=32\times|\mathbf{w}| upon using 32 bit quantization). Following [44, 26], we can also write QjISL=ℬj​log2⁡(1+S​N​Rj)superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑗ISLsubscriptℬ𝑗subscript21𝑆𝑁subscript𝑅𝑗Q_{j}^{\text{ISL}}=\mathcal{B}_{j}\log_{2}(1+SNR_{j}), where ℬjsubscriptℬ𝑗\mathcal{B}_{j} is the channel bandwidth and S​N​Rj=pS,j​Gjrx​GjtxZ​N0𝑆𝑁subscript𝑅𝑗subscript𝑝𝑆𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑗rxsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑗tx𝑍subscript𝑁0SNR_{j}=\frac{p_{S,j}G_{j}^{\text{rx}}G_{j}^{\text{tx}}}{ZN_{0}} is the signal to noise ratio between two satellites. Here, Gjrxsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑗rxG_{j}^{\text{rx}}, Gjtxsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑗txG_{j}^{\text{tx}}, Z𝑍Z, N0subscript𝑁0N_{0}, pS,jsubscript𝑝𝑆𝑗p_{S,j} are the Rx, Tx gains of the antenna, free space path loss, noise power density, and transmit power at the satellite, respectively. The corresponding energy consumption for this ISL communication procedure (at the satellite that is leaving cluster j𝑗j) can be written as follows:

ES,jtrans=pS,j⋅τS,jtrans.superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑆𝑗trans⋅subscript𝑝𝑆𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗transE_{S,j}^{\text{trans}}=p_{S,j}\cdot\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}}. (11)

Step 2-2: Satellite-side local update. After receiving the model and data, the new satellite covering cluster j𝑗j performs local updates using dataset ∪k∈GjD^kssubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠\cup_{k\in G_{j}}\hat{D}_{k}^{s} according to

𝐰S,jr+1=𝐰r−ηr​∇~​ℓS,j​(𝐰r),subscriptsuperscript𝐰𝑟1𝑆𝑗superscript𝐰𝑟subscript𝜂𝑟~∇subscriptℓ𝑆𝑗superscript𝐰𝑟\mathbf{w}^{r+1}_{S,j}=\mathbf{w}^{r}-\eta_{r}\tilde{\nabla}\ell_{S,j}(\mathbf{w}^{r}), (12)

where ∇~​ℓS,j​(𝐰)~∇subscriptℓ𝑆𝑗𝐰\tilde{\nabla}\ell_{S,j}(\mathbf{w}) is the gradient of the mini-batch defined with (4). The model update is conducted until processing all the samples in the collected dataset ∪k∈GjD^kssubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠\cup_{k\in G_{j}}\hat{D}_{k}^{s}. If the computation cannot be finished within T−τS,jtrans𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗transT-\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}} seconds, we let the satellite perform computation for T−τS,jtrans𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗transT-\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}} seconds and then move back to Step 2-1, i.e., the satellite transmits the model and the dataset to the neighboring satellite that will cover cluster j𝑗j, so that the new satellite can continue training.

These processes in Steps 2-1 and 2-2 are repeated for Njsubscript𝑁𝑗N_{j} times, which is written as

Nj=⌊mS​∑k∈Gjαk​|Dk|(T−τS,jtrans)​fS,j⌋.subscript𝑁𝑗subscript𝑚𝑆subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗transsubscript𝑓𝑆𝑗N_{j}=\left\lfloor\frac{m_{S}\sum_{k\in G_{j}}\alpha_{k}|D_{k}|}{(T-\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}})f_{S,j}}\right\rfloor. (13)

Here, fS,jsubscript𝑓𝑆𝑗f_{S,j} (in cycles/seccyclessec\text{cycles}/\text{sec}) is the CPU frequency of satellites focusing on cluster j𝑗j and mSsubscript𝑚𝑆m_{S} (in cycles/samplecyclessample\text{cycles}/\text{sample}) is the number of CPU cycles for the satellite to process one data sample. The term mS​∑k∈Gjαk​|Dk|subscript𝑚𝑆subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘m_{S}\sum_{k\in G_{j}}\alpha_{k}|D_{k}| (in cycles) in the numerator denotes the total amount of CPU cycles to finish one local epoch using the collected dataset at the satellite. The denominator denotes the number of CPU cycles that each satellite can run within the available time duration T−τS,jtrans𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗transT-\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}}. After repeating this procedure for Njsubscript𝑁𝑗N_{j} times, the (Nj+1subscript𝑁𝑗1N_{j}+1)-th satellite (i.e., the last satellite) receives the model and data, finishes the remaining updates, and then directly transmits the model and data to the next satellite for the next global round. Here, the number of CPU cycles that last satellite need to process becomes mS​∑k∈Gjαk​|Dk|−Nj​(T−τS,jtrans)​fS,jsubscript𝑚𝑆subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑁𝑗𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗transsubscript𝑓𝑆𝑗m_{S}\sum_{k\in G_{j}}\alpha_{k}|D_{k}|-N_{j}(T-\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}})f_{S,j} (in cycles). Overall, each satellite covering cluster j𝑗j will participate in the training process for τS,jlocalsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗local\tau_{S,j}^{\text{local}} seconds, where

τS,jlocal={T,(The first Nj satellites),mS​∑k∈Gjαk​|Dk|−Nj​(T−τS,jtrans)​fS,jfS,j+τS,jtrans,(The last satellite)\displaystyle\tau_{S,j}^{\text{local}}=\begin{dcases}T,\ \text{(The first $N_{j}$ satellites}),\\ \frac{m_{S}\sum_{k\in G_{j}}\alpha_{k}|D_{k}|-N_{j}(T-\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}})f_{S,j}}{f_{S,j}}\\ \ \ +\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}},\text{(The last satellite)}\end{dcases} (14)

holds. The corresponding energy consumption at each satellite becomes

ES,jlocal={κ⋅(T−τS,jtrans)fS,j3+ES,jtrans,(First Nj satellites),κ⋅(mS​∑k∈Gjαk​|Dk|−Nj​(T−τS,jtrans)​fS,j)​fS,j2+ES,jtrans,(The last satellite).\displaystyle E_{S,j}^{\text{local}}=\begin{dcases}\kappa\cdot(T-\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}})f_{S,j}^{3}+E_{S,j}^{\text{trans}},\ \text{(First $N_{j}$ satellites}),\\ \kappa\cdot\Big{(}m_{S}\sum_{k\in G_{j}}\alpha_{k}|D_{k}|-N_{j}(T-\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}})f_{S,j}\Big{)}f_{S,j}^{2}\\ \ \ +E_{S,j}^{\text{trans}},\ \text{(The last satellite)}.\end{dcases} (15)

For the first Njsubscript𝑁𝑗N_{j} satellites, ES,jlocalsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑆𝑗localE_{S,j}^{\text{local}} reflects the energy consumption for local computation (T−τS,jtrans𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗transT-\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}} seconds) and communication (τS,jtranssuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗trans\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}} seconds). For the last satellite, it consists of energy consumption for processing the remaining data samples and then communicating the model/dataset for τS,jtranssuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗trans\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}} seconds for the next global round.

Finally, based on (14), the overall latency for Step 2 at cluster j𝑗j can be written as

τS,jrep=T⋅Nj⏟Latency for the first Nj satellitessuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗repsubscript⏟⋅𝑇subscript𝑁𝑗Latency for the first Nj satellites\displaystyle\tau_{S,j}^{\text{rep}}=\underbrace{T\cdot N_{j}}_{\text{Latency for the first $N_{j}$ satellites}} (16)
+m​∑k∈Gjαk​|Dk|−Nj​(T−τS,jtrans)​fS,jfS,j+τS,jtrans⏟Latency for the last satellite.subscript⏟𝑚subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑁𝑗𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗transsubscript𝑓𝑆𝑗subscript𝑓𝑆𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗transLatency for the last satellite\displaystyle+\underbrace{\frac{m\sum_{k\in G_{j}}\alpha_{k}|D_{k}|-N_{j}(T-\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}})f_{S,j}}{f_{S,j}}+\tau_{S,j}^{\text{trans}}}_{\text{Latency for the last satellite}}. (17)

The above latency model is unique to our work that adopts ISL communications for transmitting the trained model and the offloaded dataset to the next satellite covering the cluster.

III-D Step 3: Intra-Cluster Model Aggregation

After Steps 1 and 2 are completed, the satellite that is covering cluster j𝑗j aggregates the client-side models {𝐰C,kr+1}k∈Gjsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝐶𝑘𝑟1𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗\{\mathbf{w}_{C,k}^{r+1}\}_{k\in G_{j}} and the satellite-side model 𝐰S,jr+1superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑆𝑗𝑟1\mathbf{w}_{S,j}^{r+1} according to

𝐰¯jr+1=(∑k∈Gjαk​|Dk|)⋅𝐰S,jr+1+∑k∈Gj(1−αk)​|Dk|​𝐰C,kr+1∑k∈Gj|Dk|.superscriptsubscript¯𝐰𝑗𝑟1⋅subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑆𝑗𝑟1subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗1subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝐶𝑘𝑟1subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝐷𝑘\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{j}^{r+1}=\frac{\big{(}\sum\limits_{k\in G_{j}}\alpha_{k}|D_{k}|\big{)}\cdot\mathbf{w}_{S,j}^{r+1}+\sum\limits_{k\in G_{j}}(1-\alpha_{k})|D_{k}|\mathbf{w}_{C,k}^{r+1}}{\sum\limits_{k\in G_{j}}|D_{k}|}. (18)

In this process, each client k∈Gj𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗k\in G_{j} needs to send the updated model to the satellite via uplink communication. The uplink communication time τC,kaggsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑘agg\tau_{C,k}^{\text{agg}} for client k𝑘k to upload the model can be written as

τC,kagg=S​(𝐰)bk​log2⁡(1+pC,k​|hC,k|2bk​N0),superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑘agg𝑆𝐰subscript𝑏𝑘subscript21subscript𝑝𝐶𝑘superscriptsubscriptℎ𝐶𝑘2subscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝑁0\tau_{C,k}^{\text{agg}}=\frac{S(\mathbf{w})}{b_{k}\log_{2}(1+\frac{p_{C,k}|h_{C,k}|^{2}}{b_{k}N_{0}})}, (19)

where S​(𝐰)𝑆𝐰S(\mathbf{w}) is the model size in bits, bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} is the bandwidth allocated to client k𝑘k, pC,ksubscript𝑝𝐶𝑘p_{C,k} is the transmit power of client k𝑘k, and hC,ksubscriptℎ𝐶𝑘h_{C,k} is the channel between client k𝑘k and the satellite covering the cluster. As in [45], we model the channel hC,ksubscriptℎ𝐶𝑘h_{C,k} using large-scale fading, which is dominant compared to the effect of small-scale fading. We let |hC,k|2=dC,k−ξsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝐶𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑑𝐶𝑘𝜉|h_{C,k}|^{2}=d_{C,k}^{-\xi}, where dC,ksubscript𝑑𝐶𝑘d_{C,k} denotes the distance between client k𝑘k and the satellite covering the corresponding cluster, and ξ𝜉\xi is the pathloss exponent. We note that the system parameters should be selected to make the aggregation delay τC,kaggsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑘agg\tau_{C,k}^{\text{agg}} smaller than the coverage duration T𝑇T. Otherwise, the satellite is not able to aggregate the models within T𝑇T seconds. The corresponding energy consumption for model transmission at client k𝑘k becomes

EC,kagg=pC,k⋅τC,kagg.subscriptsuperscript𝐸agg𝐶𝑘⋅subscript𝑝𝐶𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜏agg𝐶𝑘E^{\text{agg}}_{C,k}=p_{C,k}\cdot\tau^{\text{agg}}_{C,k}. (20)

III-E Step 4: Global Model Aggregation

After the intra-cluster model aggregation process in Step 3, J𝐽J different satellites obtain different models 𝐰¯1r+1,𝐰¯2r+1,…,𝐰¯Jr+1superscriptsubscript¯𝐰1𝑟1superscriptsubscript¯𝐰2𝑟1…superscriptsubscript¯𝐰𝐽𝑟1\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{1}^{r+1},\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{2}^{r+1},\dots,\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{J}^{r+1} corresponding to each cluster. Following the process of [26, 31], these models can be aggregated according to

𝐰r+1=1J​∑j=1J𝐰¯jr+1superscript𝐰𝑟11𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽superscriptsubscript¯𝐰𝑗𝑟1\mathbf{w}^{r+1}=\frac{1}{J}\sum_{j=1}^{J}\bar{\mathbf{w}}_{j}^{r+1} (21)

at the ground station with the aid of ISL communications. We assume a fixed delay τjglobsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑗glob\tau_{j}^{\text{glob}} for this process for each cluster j𝑗j, i.e., τjglobsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑗glob\tau_{j}^{\text{glob}} denotes the delay for the satellite covering cluster j𝑗j to transmit the aggregated model to the ground station. After the global model 𝐰r+1superscript𝐰𝑟1\mathbf{w}^{r+1} is constructed by aggregating the models of all clusters according to (21), at the beginning of next round222In the next round, each cluster could be covered by another orbit different from the one in the previous round. In this case, the satellite in the previous round can transmit its data/model to the new satellite through inter-plane ISL., 𝐰r+1superscript𝐰𝑟1\mathbf{w}^{r+1} is sent to all clients in the system which requires additional latency of τjsyncsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑗sync\tau_{j}^{\text{sync}} for cluster j𝑗j.

Steps 1, 2, 3 and 4 are repeated for R𝑅R global rounds, with Steps 1 and 2 working in parallel. Algorithm 1 summarizes the overall process of our satellite-assisted FL methodology.

IV Convergence Analysis

In this section, we analyze the convergence behavior of our algorithm. Given D^kcsuperscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑐\hat{D}_{k}^{c} and D^kssuperscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠\hat{D}_{k}^{s} for all k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, we define our objective function as

F​(𝐰)=1J​∑j=1JFj​(𝐰),𝐹𝐰1𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐽subscript𝐹𝑗𝐰F(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{J}\sum_{j=1}^{J}F_{j}(\mathbf{w}), (22)

where

Fj​(𝐰)=(∑k∈Gj|D^ks|)​ℓS,j​(𝐰)+∑k∈Gj|D^kc|​ℓC,k​(𝐰)∑k∈Gj|Dk|subscript𝐹𝑗𝐰subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠subscriptℓ𝑆𝑗𝐰subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑐subscriptℓ𝐶𝑘𝐰subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝐷𝑘\displaystyle F_{j}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{\big{(}\sum\limits_{k\in G_{j}}|\hat{D}_{k}^{s}|\big{)}\ell_{S,j}(\mathbf{w})+\sum\limits_{k\in G_{j}}|\hat{D}_{k}^{c}|\ell_{C,k}(\mathbf{w})}{\sum\limits_{k\in G_{j}}|D_{k}|} (23)
=(∑k∈Gjαk​|Dk|)​ℓS,j​(𝐰)+∑k∈Gj(1−αk)​|Dk|​ℓC,k​(𝐰)∑k∈Gj|Dk|absentsubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscriptℓ𝑆𝑗𝐰subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗1subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscriptℓ𝐶𝑘𝐰subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝐷𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{\big{(}\sum\limits_{k\in G_{j}}\alpha_{k}|D_{k}|\big{)}\ell_{S,j}(\mathbf{w})+\sum\limits_{k\in G_{j}}(1-\alpha_{k})|D_{k}|\ell_{C,k}(\mathbf{w})}{\sum\limits_{k\in G_{j}}|D_{k}|}

is the local objective function of cluster j𝑗j defined as the weighted sum of the client-side objective functions in (2) and the satellite-side objective function in (4). For analysis, we take the following assumptions that are adopted in existing FL literature [46, 47, 48, 49].

Assumption 1.

(L𝐿L-smoothness) The satellite-side and client-side objective functions ℓS,j​(⋅)subscriptℓ𝑆𝑗⋅\ell_{S,j}(\cdot) and ℓC,k​(⋅)subscriptℓ𝐶𝑘⋅\ell_{C,k}(\cdot) are L𝐿L-smooth functions, i.e., ‖∇ℓS,j​(𝐰)−∇ℓS,j​(𝐯)‖≤L​‖𝐰−𝐯‖norm∇subscriptℓ𝑆𝑗𝐰∇subscriptℓ𝑆𝑗𝐯𝐿norm𝐰𝐯\|\nabla\ell_{S,j}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla\ell_{S,j}(\mathbf{v})\|\leq L\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{v}\| and ‖∇ℓC,k​(𝐰)−∇ℓC,k​(𝐯)‖≤L​‖𝐰−𝐯‖norm∇subscriptℓ𝐶𝑘𝐰∇subscriptℓ𝐶𝑘𝐯𝐿norm𝐰𝐯\|\nabla\ell_{C,k}(\mathbf{w})-\nabla\ell_{C,k}(\mathbf{v})\|\leq L\|\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{v}\| for any 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}.

Assumption 2.

(Data variability) The local data variability of each client k𝑘k is bounded as ‖∇ℓ​(x;𝐰)−∇ℓ​(x′;𝐰)‖≤ρ​‖x−x′‖norm∇ℓ𝑥𝐰∇ℓsuperscript𝑥′𝐰𝜌norm𝑥superscript𝑥′\|\nabla\ell(x;\mathbf{w})-\nabla\ell(x^{\prime};\mathbf{w})\|\leq\rho\|x-x^{\prime}\| for any x,x′∈D^kc𝑥superscript𝑥′superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑐x,x^{\prime}\in\hat{D}_{k}^{c}. Similarly, ‖∇ℓ​(x;𝐰)−∇ℓ​(x′;𝐰)‖≤ρ​‖x−x′‖norm∇ℓ𝑥𝐰∇ℓsuperscript𝑥′𝐰𝜌norm𝑥superscript𝑥′\|\nabla\ell(x;\mathbf{w})-\nabla\ell(x^{\prime};\mathbf{w})\|\leq\rho\|x-x^{\prime}\| holds for any x,x′∈∪k∈GjD^ks𝑥superscript𝑥′subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠x,x^{\prime}\in\cup_{k\in G_{j}}\hat{D}_{k}^{s} for the dataset at the satellite.

Note that Assumption 1 guarantees the L𝐿L-smoothness of the global loss function in (22). To see the effect of the number of processed data samples at each client, we derive the convergence bound considering local update with mini-batch size λC,krsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝐶𝑘𝑟\lambda_{C,k}^{r} at client k𝑘k at round r𝑟r. To gain further insights, we also introduce the mini-batch size λS,jrsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑆𝑗𝑟\lambda_{S,j}^{r} at the satellite covering cluster j𝑗j for analysis. Now we state the following theorem which describes the convergence behavior of the algorithm.

Theorem 1.

(Convergence bound) Suppose Assumptions 1, 2 hold. The term ΩΩ\Omega that appears in the right-hand side of (24) captures effect of the number of data samples λC,krsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝐶𝑘𝑟\lambda_{C,k}^{r} and λS,jrsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑆𝑗𝑟\lambda_{S,j}^{r} processed at each client and satellite, respectively. As λC,krsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝐶𝑘𝑟\lambda_{C,k}^{r} and λS,jrsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑆𝑗𝑟\lambda_{S,j}^{r} increase, we can achieve a smaller ΩΩ\Omega, which leads to a tighter convergence bound at a specific global round r𝑟r. This advantage is the cost of an increased training time for processing more data samples. VC,ksubscript𝑉𝐶𝑘V_{C,k} and VS,jsubscript𝑉𝑆𝑗V_{S,j} in (26) and (27) are the sample variance of the dataset |D^kc|superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑐|\hat{D}_{k}^{c}| at client k𝑘k and the dataset ∪k∈GjD^kssubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝐷𝑘𝑠\cup_{k\in G_{j}}\hat{D}_{k}^{s} collected at the satellite of cluster j𝑗j, respectively. The convergence of the algorithm can be guaranteed by decaying the learning rate to satisfy ΓR=∑r=0R−1ηr→∞subscriptΓ𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟0𝑅1subscript𝜂𝑟→\Gamma_{R}=\sum_{r=0}^{R-1}\eta_{r}\rightarrow\infty and ∑r=0R−1ηr2<∞superscriptsubscript𝑟0𝑅1superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑟2\sum_{r=0}^{R-1}\eta_{r}^{2}<\infty. One specific example is ηr=η01+rsubscript𝜂𝑟subscript𝜂01𝑟\eta_{r}=\frac{\eta_{0}}{1+r}, which has been also adopted in prior works [50, 51]. It can be seen that the right-hand side of (24) goes to zero as R𝑅R grows, guaranteeing convergence to the stationary point of the non-convex ML loss function.

V Network Optimization for Satellite-Assisted FL

In this section, we formulate the network optimization problem to minimize the training time. Based on the results established in Section III, we start by analyzing the latency of our satellite-assisted methodology.

V-A Latency Analysis for Satellite-Assisted FL

We first focus on the latency of a specific cluster j𝑗j. The running time at cluster j𝑗j to finish a single global round can be written as follows:

τj=max⁡{τC,j,τS,j}⏟Latency until intra-cluster agg.+τjglob.subscript𝜏𝑗subscript⏟subscript𝜏𝐶𝑗subscript𝜏𝑆𝑗Latency until intra-cluster agg.superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑗glob\tau_{j}=\underbrace{\max\{\tau_{C,j},\tau_{S,j}\}}_{\text{Latency until intra-cluster agg.}}+\ \tau_{j}^{\text{glob}}. (28)

In (28), the first term max⁡{τC,j,τS,j}subscript𝜏𝐶𝑗subscript𝜏𝑆𝑗\max\{\tau_{C,j},\tau_{S,j}\} is the delay until the intra-cluster aggregation process is finished in cluster j𝑗j, while the last term τjglobsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑗glob\tau_{j}^{\text{glob}} is the additional delay for global aggregation defined in Section III-E. Here, the first term max⁡{τC,j,τS,j}subscript𝜏𝐶𝑗subscript𝜏𝑆𝑗\max\{\tau_{C,j},\tau_{S,j}\} is affected by two parameters. First, τC,jsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑗\tau_{C,j} denotes the delay until all clients in cluster j𝑗j to finish local updates and send the updated models to the satellite for intra-cluster aggregation. The second variable τS,jsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗\tau_{S,j} is the satellite-side latency, which denotes the delay until the last satellite in cluster j𝑗j finishes its computation.

Now we observe the individual terms. Specifically, τC,jsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑗\tau_{C,j} can be written as

τC,j=τjsync⏟model sync+Yj⏟client model update and upload,subscript𝜏𝐶𝑗subscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑗syncmodel syncsubscript⏟subscript𝑌𝑗client model update and upload\tau_{C,j}=\underbrace{\tau_{j}^{\text{sync}}}_{\text{model sync}}+\underbrace{Y_{j}}_{\text{client model update and upload}}, (29)

where τjsyncsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑗sync\tau_{j}^{\text{sync}} is the model synchronization latency for cluster j𝑗j as defined in Section III-E and Yjsubscript𝑌𝑗Y_{j} is the latency at cluster j𝑗j to finish client-side local computations and intra-cluster aggregation. Specifically, we have the following result:

Yj={T⋅Nj+maxk∈Gj⁡{τC,kagg}(Case 1)maxk∈Gj⁡{max⁡(T⋅⌊τC,k′localT⌋,τC,klocal)+τC,kagg},(Case 2),T⋅(⌊τC,k′localT⌋+1)+maxk∈Gj⁡{τC,kagg},otherwise (Case 3),subscript𝑌𝑗cases⋅𝑇subscript𝑁𝑗subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑘agg(Case 1)otherwisesubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗⋅𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶superscript𝑘′local𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑘localsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑘agg(Case 2)otherwise⋅𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶superscript𝑘′local𝑇1subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑘aggotherwise (Case 3),otherwiseY_{j}=\begin{dcases}T\cdot N_{j}+\max_{k\in G_{j}}\{\tau_{C,k}^{\text{agg}}\}\ \ \text{(Case 1)}\\ \max_{k\in G_{j}}\Big{\{}\max\Big{(}T\cdot\Big{\lfloor}\frac{\tau_{C,k^{\prime}}^{\text{local}}}{T}\Big{\rfloor},\tau_{C,k}^{\text{local}}\Big{)}+\tau_{C,k}^{\text{agg}}\Big{\}},\ \ \text{(Case 2)},\\ T\cdot\Big{(}\Big{\lfloor}\frac{\tau_{C,k^{\prime}}^{\text{local}}}{T}\Big{\rfloor}+1\Big{)}+\max_{k\in G_{j}}\{\tau_{C,k}^{\text{agg}}\},\ \text{otherwise (Case 3),}\end{dcases} (30)

where k′=arg​maxk∈Gj⁡{τC,klocal}superscript𝑘′subscriptargmax𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑘localk^{\prime}=\operatorname*{arg\,max}_{k\in G_{j}}\{\tau_{C,k}^{\text{local}}\}. To gain insights into (30), it is first important to note that the models sent from the clients are aggregated at the last satellite of the cluster. Moreover, from (13), recall that the satellite-side computation at cluster j𝑗j is finished at the (Nj+1)subscript𝑁𝑗1(N_{j}+1)-th satellite. This corresponds to case 1 of (30). However, some clients may not finish local updates until the (Nj+1)subscript𝑁𝑗1(N_{j}+1)-th satellite arrives, i.e., maxk∈Gj⁡{τC,klocal}>T⋅Njsubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶𝑘local⋅𝑇subscript𝑁𝑗\max_{k\in G_{j}}\{\tau_{C,k}^{\text{local}}\}>T\cdot N_{j}. For this case, the delay is affected by client k′superscript𝑘′k^{\prime} that has the largest computation time in the cluster, and either the ⌊τC,k′localT⌋superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶superscript𝑘′local𝑇\Big{\lfloor}\frac{\tau_{C,k^{\prime}}^{\text{local}}}{T}\Big{\rfloor}-th satellite or the (⌊τC,k′localT⌋+1)superscriptsubscript𝜏𝐶superscript𝑘′local𝑇1\Big{(}\Big{\lfloor}\frac{\tau_{C,k^{\prime}}^{\text{local}}}{T}\Big{\rfloor}+1\Big{)}-th satellite aggregates the models depending on the aggregation time. These scenarios correspond to cases 2 and 3 in (30).

On the other hand, the satellite-side latency τS,jsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗\tau_{S,j} can be written as

τS,j=τjsync⏟model sync+τS,jrep⏟Satellite-side model update,subscript𝜏𝑆𝑗subscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑗syncmodel syncsubscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗repSatellite-side model update\tau_{S,j}=\underbrace{\tau_{j}^{\text{sync}}}_{\text{model sync}}+\underbrace{\tau_{S,j}^{\text{rep}}}_{\text{Satellite-side model update}}, (31)

where τS,jrepsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗rep\tau_{S,j}^{\text{rep}} is the satellite-side delay to process all data samples, as defined in (16).

Finally, the completion time for one global FL round can be written as the maximum of the delays of all clusters. This results in

τround=maxj∈𝒥⁡{τj}superscript𝜏roundsubscript𝑗𝒥subscript𝜏𝑗\displaystyle\tau^{\text{round}}=\max_{j\in\mathcal{J}}\{\tau_{j}\} (32)

In (35a), we optimize α¯¯𝛼\bar{\alpha} in (1) that describes the portion of data offloading at each client, γ¯¯𝛾\bar{\gamma} in (6) which denotes the portion of data processed at each client in one global round, f¯Ssubscript¯𝑓𝑆\bar{f}_{S} describing the CPU frequencies of satellites, and b¯¯𝑏\bar{b}, which describes the bandwidth allocated to the clients333Once the variables are optimized, we can fix the amount of data offloading until the environment drastically changes (e.g., when the battery charging of satellites is no longer available due to the rotation of the Earth)..

Constraint (35b) indicates that αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} is upper bounded by the portion of non-sensitive samples in client k𝑘k, while (35c) shows the feasible value of each γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k}. Constraint (35d) indicates that fS,jsubscript𝑓𝑆𝑗f_{S,j} is upper bounded by the maximum CPU frequency of the satellite. The constraint for the bandwidth in each cluster is given by (35e), and the constraint for the energy consumption at each client is provided in (35f). (35g) shows the battery constraints of the satellites covering the clusters in 𝒥sunsuperscript𝒥sun\mathcal{J}^{\text{sun}}, i.e., the clusters that are facing the sun and that make battery charging of the satellites possible. Ejoriginalsubscriptsuperscript𝐸original𝑗E^{\text{original}}_{j} is the battery of the satellite at the moment of joining cluster j𝑗j, ES,jlocalsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑆𝑗localE_{S,j}^{\text{local}} is the energy consumption defined in (15) and τS,jlocalsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗local\tau_{S,j}^{\text{local}} is the time duration for each satellite to participate in the training process as defined in (14). τS,jlocal⋅Pjsun⋅superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗localsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑗sun\tau_{S,j}^{\text{local}}\cdot P_{j}^{\text{sun}} is the amount of energy that could be charged from the sun during τS,jlocalsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗local\tau_{S,j}^{\text{local}} seconds, where Pjsun>0superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑗sun0P_{j}^{\text{sun}}>0 denotes the power of the sun near cluster j𝑗j. ψ𝜓\psi is the minimum battery constraint that should be satisfied at the satellite when leaving the FL system for future uses. (35i) is the constraint for the convergence bound in (24) to guarantee a certain level of learning performance. Finally, (35j) is the communication load constraint during data offloading in each cluster, where Ajsubscript𝐴𝑗A_{j} denotes the total amount of data transmitted from the clients to the satellite in cluster j𝑗j. By limiting the amount of communication to the satellite within each cluster for data offloading, we prevent excessive delay, energy consumption, and communication during FL.

V-C Solution: Iterative Algorithm

The above problem turns out to be a non-convex optimization problem. We first relax this problem by setting γkr=1−αksuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑟1subscript𝛼𝑘\gamma_{k}^{r}=1-\alpha_{k}, which means that each client processes all data samples that have not been offloaded to the satellite. Based on this strategy, it can be seen that the convergence bound in (1) is minimized given {αk}k∈𝒦subscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑘𝒦\{\alpha_{k}\}_{k\in\mathcal{K}}, resolving the constraints (35i) and (35c). This theoretically guarantees the best convergence bound for our algorithm, as can be seen from (24).

To tackle this non-convex optimization problem, we develop a method based on block-coordinated descent consisting of I𝐼I iterations. Starting from initial values α¯(0),f¯S(0),b¯(0)superscript¯𝛼0superscriptsubscript¯𝑓𝑆0superscript¯𝑏0\bar{\alpha}^{(0)},\bar{f}_{S}^{(0)},\bar{b}^{(0)}, we obtain α¯(I),f¯S(I),b¯(I)superscript¯𝛼𝐼superscriptsubscript¯𝑓𝑆𝐼superscript¯𝑏𝐼\bar{\alpha}^{(I)},\bar{f}_{S}^{(I)},\bar{b}^{(I)} after I𝐼I iterations, where each iteration entails the following three steps.

(i) Optimize α¯¯𝛼\bar{\alpha} given f¯Ssubscript¯𝑓𝑆\bar{f}_{S}, b¯¯𝑏\bar{b}. Our first step is to optimize α¯¯𝛼\bar{\alpha} given other variables fixed:

minα¯⁡τround​subject to:​(35b),(35j).subscript¯𝛼superscript𝜏roundsubject to:35b35j\displaystyle\ \min_{\bar{\alpha}}\tau^{\text{round}}\ \text{subject to:}\ (\ref{constraint:alpha}),(\ref{eq:constraint_comm_group}). (36)

In this first subproblem, we consider two terms that are affected by α¯¯𝛼\bar{\alpha}: Yjsubscript𝑌𝑗Y_{j} and τS,jrepsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗rep\tau_{S,j}^{\text{rep}}. From (16), we note that τS,jrepsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗rep\tau_{S,j}^{\text{rep}} is an increasing function of the total amount of data offloaded within each cluster, i.e., ∑k∈Gjαk​|Dk|=Ajsubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐴𝑗\sum_{k\in G_{j}}\alpha_{k}|D_{k}|=A_{j}, but is not affected by the individual αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} values when Ajsubscript𝐴𝑗A_{j} is given. On the other hand, Yjsubscript𝑌𝑗Y_{j} in (30) is an increasing function of each αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k}. To minimize the overall latency, we first aim to find the best αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} that minimizes Yjsubscript𝑌𝑗Y_{j} given Ajsubscript𝐴𝑗A_{j} fixed for each j𝑗j. This subproblem for each cluster j𝑗j can be formulated as follows:

(37)

Note that in (30), Njsubscript𝑁𝑗N_{j} is also a fixed value when ∑k∈Gjαk​|Dk|=Ajsubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑗subscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐴𝑗\sum_{k\in G_{j}}\alpha_{k}|D_{k}|=A_{j} is given. According to (30), there are three different cases we need to consider when analyzing Yjsubscript𝑌𝑗Y_{j}.

We have the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

The optimal solution α¯∗=[α1∗,α2∗,…,αK∗]superscript¯𝛼superscriptsubscript𝛼1superscriptsubscript𝛼2…superscriptsubscript𝛼𝐾\bar{\alpha}^{*}=[\alpha_{1}^{*},\alpha_{2}^{*},\dots,\alpha_{K}^{*}] of (36) can be obtained by Algorithm 2.

Intuitively, as more data samples in cluster j𝑗j are offloaded to the satellite, the satellite-side computation time increases, which results in increased τS,jrepsuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑆𝑗rep\tau_{S,j}^{\text{rep}}. At the same time, when Ajsubscript𝐴𝑗A_{j} becomes too large, Yjsubscript𝑌𝑗Y_{j} also turns out to be an increasing function of offloaded data. This makes sense because even when the clients finish the local computations quickly, they do not send the updated models until the last satellite covers the cluster. These parts are captured in our analysis.

(ii) Optimize f¯Ssubscript¯𝑓𝑆\bar{f}_{S} given α¯¯𝛼\bar{\alpha}, b¯¯𝑏\bar{b}. Given α¯¯𝛼\bar{\alpha} and b¯¯𝑏\bar{b}, our second subproblem can be written as

VI Experimental Results

We conduct experiments using three benchmark datasets for FL: MNIST, FMNIST and CIFAR-10. We train a convolutional neural network with two convolutional layers and two fully connected layers using MNIST. For FMNIST, we adopt a different model with two convolutional layers and one fully connected layer. Finally, we utilize the VGG-11 model for the CIFAR-10 dataset. We use a PyTorch framework with NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3080Ti GPU to train the ML models.

VI-A Simulation Setup and Baselines

For simulations, we consider a setup with K=50𝐾50K=50 clients and J=5𝐽5J=5 clusters, each cluster having 10 clients in its region. The altitudes of the LEO satellite orbits are 784784784 km from the ground [18]. In each global round, the LEO satellites in the same orbit serially cover a specific cluster with the squared region of 120012001200 m ×\times 120012001200 m [18]. Among 5 clusters, we assume that 3 clusters are facing the sun with Pjsun=5superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑗sun5P_{j}^{\text{sun}}=5 W. Other parameter values are shown in Table I, where the satellite-specific parameters are mostly adopted from [37, 26]. For MNIST and FMNIST which utilize relatively small models, we set Eoriginal=500superscript𝐸original500E^{\text{original}}=500 J, ψ=100𝜓100\psi=100 J. For CIFAR-10 we set Eoriginal=2000superscript𝐸original2000E^{\text{original}}=2000 J, ψ=250𝜓250\psi=250 J for training a larger model. The effect of other Eoriginalsuperscript𝐸originalE^{\text{original}} values is also studied in Section VI-C. We set αkmax=0.8superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘max0.8\alpha_{k}^{\text{max}}=0.8 for all users.

FL implementation. To model different data distributions across users, we consider both the IID (independent, identically distributed) setup where all clients’ local datasets have same distributions, and the non-IID setup where each client has a different data distribution with other clients. In the IID scenario, the training set of dataset is distributed across the users uniformly at random. For the non-IID case, we first sort the training set based on the labels and divide it into 100 shards with equal sizes, as done in [1]. Then, we randomly allocate 2 shards to each client, which introduces class non-IIDness across users. Each client is allocated with 120012001200 data samples for MNIST and FMNIST, as each dataset consists of 60,0006000060,000 train samples. For the CIFAR-10 which consists of 50,0005000050,000 train samples, we let each client to have 100010001000 samples in its local dataset. During the local update process, each client trains the model using mini-batch stochastic gradient descent with momentum of 0.9. When training is finished, the test accuracy of the constructed global model is measured using the test samples in each dataset.

Baselines. We consider the following baselines for comparison. To confirm the advantage of adopting satellites, we first consider the scheme where all data samples are processed at the client-side without offloading them to the satellites. The satellites are utilized to only aggregate the models of the clients in each cluster. This baseline produces the same model with the commonly adopted FL strategy for terrestrial networks [1]. Secondly, we let clients to offload all the non-sensitive samples to the satellite, i.e., αk=αkmaxsubscript𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘max\alpha_{k}=\alpha_{k}^{\text{max}}. This baseline maximizes the satellite-side computation/communication burdens for model update and ISL transmission. Finally, we vary the portion of data samples offloaded from the devices to satellites, and compare the results with ours. These baselines are considered to see the performance of arbitrary data offloading strategies that are not tailored to our delay model. For a fair comparison, we optimized the variables of all baselines to minimize latency while satisfying the optimization constraints. Specifically, for the terrestrial-only baseline, we optimized the user bandwidth to minimize latency, where the latency model of this scheme can be simply obtained by inserting αk=0subscript𝛼𝑘0\alpha_{k}=0 to (34) for all k=1,2,…,K𝑘12…𝐾k=1,2,\dots,K. For the satellite-based baselines, we also optimize the CPU frequency of the satellite to satisfy the satellite-side battery constraints in (35g) and (35h), depending on whether the satellite is facing the sun or not. We implement all schemes including ours using the well-known FedAvg algorithm [1] for a fair comparison.

VI-B FL Performance and Latency

Fig. 2 shows our main experimental results, comparing the test accuracies of different schemes as a function of training time. We make the following key observations. First, the scheme that utilizes only the client-side computations without any data offloading to satellites, achieves the worst performance. One trivial reason is that this scheme ignores the satellite-side computation, not taking the benefit of parallel client-satellite computing. Another important factor is the non-IID data distribution across clients. Without any data offloading, the performance of this baseline becomes extremely limited under the non-IID setting due to the biased local datasets of clients. Related to this phenomenon, it can be seen that the performance gap between the IID and non-IID cases decreases as more data samples are offloaded to the satellite. The satellite-side dataset collected from different users can somewhat resolve the issue that arises from the non-IID data distribution. However, offloading too many data samples to the satellite will slow down the training process, causing latency issues. This can be confirmed by comparing the scheme that offloads all non-sensitive samples (i.e., αmax=0.8superscript𝛼max0.8\alpha^{\text{max}}=0.8 portion of local dataset) to the satellite, and the schemes that only offload 30%percent3030\% or 40%percent4040\% of the local datasets. Even when the maximum computation power of the satellite is large, collecting large volumes of data at the satellite can cause significant delays due to the battery constraint at individual satellites.

For our scheme, the average portions of offloaded data at each client are 56.89%percent56.8956.89\%, 55.23%percent55.2355.23\%, and 67.23%percent67.2367.23\% for MNIST, FMNIST, and CIFAR-10, respectively. Compared to the baselines, note that in our scheme, the clients may offload different portions of samples depending on their computation power, transmit power, and whether the cluster is facing the sun or not. Overall, the results in Fig. 2 shows that the proposed methodology can provide significant benefits by strategically taking advantage of satellites in FL.

In Fig. 3, we compare the latency of different schemes to achieve a certain level of accuracy. The target accuracies are set to be 97%, 88%, 77% for MNIST, FMNIST, CIFAR-10, respectively, in the IID setup. The overall results are consistent with Fig. 2, confirming the effectiveness of the proposed FL approach tailored to ground-to-satellite integrated networks.

VI-C Ablation Studies and Further Experiments

Effect of satellite-side battery. To gain insights into the effect of the sun for battery charging, in Fig. 4, we compare the portion of offloaded data samples within each cluster of our approach. CIFAR-10 is utilized for training, and the portion of non-sensitive samples are set to be αmax=0.8superscript𝛼max0.8\alpha^{\text{max}}=0.8 as in Fig. 2. We have the following main observations. First, under our simulation setup, the clients in the clusters that are facing the sun (red bars) tend to offload all of the non-sensitive data samples to the corresponding satellite, as the solar-powered satellites have less battery issues when they are facing the sun. On the other hand, if the cluster is not facing the sun (gray bars), the clients offload less data due to the satellite-side battery constraint. As the satellite has more battery in the beginning of training (i.e., as Eoriginalsuperscript𝐸originalE^{\text{original}} increases), the clients tend to offload more data as the satellites can more easily satisfy the battery constraints. The overall results show that the proposed scheme can strategically optimize the amount of data to be offloaded and the satellite-side computation power, depending on whether the cluster is facing the sun or not.

Compatibility with other FL algorithm. In Section VI-B, we made a fair comparison between our approach and other baselines by adopting FedAvg to all schemes. To further confirm the advantage of our algorithm, we now use another widely adopted FL algorithm, FedProx [52], in all baselines and our scheme for performance comparison. Fig. 5 shows the result in the non-IID setup. The results are consistent with the ones in previous subsection, further confirming the effectiveness and applicability of our satellite-assisted FL methodology.

Practical varying coverage times. Instead of using a fixed the coverage time T𝑇T, we also conduct experiments with varying coverage times using the Walker-Star constellation model in Fig. 6. We specifically use the walkerStar function [53] in MATLAB to create a satellite constellation. We consider 50 satellites equally distributed across 5 orbits with altitude of 784 km and inclination of 90∘superscript9090^{\circ}. The minimum elevation angle to communicate is set to 15∘superscript1515^{\circ}, and 50 clients are distributed in a specific region with latitude of 40∘superscript4040^{\circ} N and longitude of 86∘superscript8686^{\circ} W. Based on the constructed constellation and the location of the ground cluster, we obtained the coverage times of satellites over the target region using the accessIntervals function. Since the coverage time of each satellite can be obtained prior to optimization, we optimize the amount of data offloading considering the average coverage time of future satellites, which is 408 sec. All remaining setups are the same as in Section VI-B. Fig. 7 shows the results in the IID setup. The results consistently confirm the advantage of the proposed methodology.

VII Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed a satellite-assisted FL methodology that enables ground users in remote areas to collaboratively train an ML model, without requiring terrestrial communication infrastructures. By strategically taking advantage of satellites as edge computing units, model aggregators, and relays, the proposed methodology can speed up the FL process in ground-to-satellite integrated networks. We theoretically analyzed the convergence behavior of our approach, and optimized network resources to minimize the latency. Experimental results confirmed the advantage of the proposed idea compared to baselines, and provided insights into our network optimization solutions. We believe that our solution can provide a new direction to FL over hybrid terrestrial and non-terrestrial networks, where reducing the training time based on cooperation among ground users and satellites is of paramount importance. One interesting future direction is to extend our idea to the ground-air-space three layer network, having devices/sensors on the ground, UAVs or drones in the sky, and satellites in the space.

It can be seen that

holds, where (a)𝑎(a) is obtained by taking the expectation with respect to the mini-batch.
